choices.text: The distal urethral sphincter is made up of striated muscle
The distal urethral sphincter is supplied by L1-L5 fibres via the pudendal nerve
The epithelium is closely adherent to the smooth muscle in the region of the trigone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the anatomy of urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
The distal urethral sphincter is supplied by S2-S4 fibres via the pudendal nerve.

Urinary bladder -

  • Lined by transitional epithelium (urothelium).
  • The trigone has the ureteric orifices at its posterolateral angles and internal urethral orifice at its apex.
  • Over the trigone is a thin layer of smooth muscle to which the epithelium is closely adherent (The epithelium is only loosely adherent in the remaining part of the bladder).
  • The muscularis propria of the bladder is formed by detrusor muscle. Its contraction causes bladder emptying.

Proximal/Internal urethral sphincter -

  • Lined by smooth muscle.
  • Innervated by sympathetic fibres in men which prevents retrograde ejaculation.

Distal/External urethral sphincter -

  • Horseshoe-shaped mass of striated muscle.
  • Lies anterior and distal to the prostate in males, or in the proximal two-thirds of the female urethra.
  • Supplied by S2-S4 fibres via the pudendal nerve and by somatic fibres passing through the inferior hypogastric plexus.

Urinary bladder is a hollow muscular layer and consists of three layers: lamina propria, smooth muscle and urothelium. The lamina propria contains a rich plexus of vessels, nerves and lymphatics. The detrusor is made up of a complex haphazard arrangement of smooth muscle, which acts as functional syncytium, and elastic connective tissue, which gives the bladder its viscoelastic properties. The urothelium is an active layer that not only acts as a barrier to protect underlying stroma from irritant urinary toxins and bacteria but also has a role in afferent signalling within the bladder; defects in the urothelial lining are thought to lead to several chronic benign bladder conditions.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1486-1487

choices.text: The superior and inferior vesical arteries are derived from the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery
Branches from the obturator and inferior gluteal arteries (and from the uterine and vaginal arteries in females) also help to supply the bladder
The veins form a plexus on the lateral and inferior surfaces of the bladder
In males the prostatic plexus is continuous with the vesical plexus, which drains into the external iliac vein

questions.text: Which statement is not correct regarding arterial and venous supply of urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Arterial supply of urinary bladder -

  • The main arterial supply of the bladder is the superior and inferior vesical arteries (derived from the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery).
  • Branches from the obturator and inferior gluteal arteries (and from the uterine and vaginal arteries in females) also help to supply the bladder.

Venous drainage -

  • The veins form a plexus on the lateral and inferior surfaces of the bladder. Finally drain into the internal iliac veins.
  • In males, the prostatic plexus is continuous with the vesical plexus.
  • In females, similar large veins are continuous with the vaginal plexus.

Arterial supply

  • Superior vesical artery (from the umbilical artery, which arises from the internal iliac artery).
  • Inferior vesical artery (directly from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, or in females from the vaginal artery, which arises from the internal iliac artery).
  • Division of the contralateral superior vesical pedicle can aid cephalad mobilisation of the bladder for psoas hitch procedures.

Venous drainage Vesical plexuses on the lateral and inferior surfaces of the bladder drain into the internal iliac vein (the prostatic plexus in males and the vaginal plexus in females are continuous with the vesical plexus).

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1486.

questions.text: Following x ray is associated with which congenital urogenital condition?
questions.solution:
The X ray shows separation of the pubic bones with non-united pubic symphysis. This is most likely a case of ectopia vesicae (bladder exstrophy).

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital disorder in which the bladder exposed on the outside of the abdomen due to a defect in the anterior abdominal wall.

Male to female ratio is 4:1.

It is associated with -

  • Epispadias
  • Increased risk of bladder cancer
  • Urinary incontinence
  • In males - bilateral inguinal hernia, undescended testis
  • In females - bifid clitoris, wide open pelvis (duck gait), wide labia

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1492.

questions.text: A suspected case of bladder trauma presents with severe pain the hypogastric region. While undergoing examination, he suddenly collapses. His cystogram is shown below. After initial stabilisation of the patient, what is the preferred modality of treatment?
questions.solution:
The cystogram shows leakage of contrast into the peritoneal cavity. This along with the hypogastric pain and syncope, point to a diagnosis of intraperitoneal rupture of bladder.

Management includes immediate exploration.

  • A lower midline laparotomy is performed.
  • The edges of the rent are trimmed and sutured.
  • A suprapubic and a urethral catheter are placed.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1520.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause for urinary retention?
questions.solution:
Urinary retention is defined as the inability to pass urine despite persistent effort. It can be classified as acute (painful inability to pass urine with relief of pain on catheterisation) or chronic (painless, elevated residual volume after passing urine).

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1507.

choices.text: The normal bladder will accept approximately 400-550 mL when filled at room temperature at a rate of
The pressure increase in the bladder should be more than 15 cm H2O
Phasic pressure increases should not be seen
The normal voiding pressure should not exceed 60 cm H2O in men

questions.text: All of the following are normal urodynamic findings, except?
questions.solution:
Urodynamic study findings:

  • The normal bladder will accept approximately 400-550 mL when filled at room temperature at a rate of <50 mL/min.
  • The pressure increase in the bladder should be less than 15 cm H2O.
  • Phasic pressure increases should not be seen. When present, they may be indicative of detrusor instability.
  • The normal voiding pressure should not exceed 60 cm H2O in men and about 40 cm H2O in women, with a flow rate of between 20 mL/s and 25 mL/s.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 81 Urinary symptoms and investigations, Pg:1463-1465.

questions.text: Most common primary bladder calculus is composed of?
questions.solution:
Primary Bladder stone is due to nutritional deficiency in Vitamins A and B6, Magnesium, Phosphate and a reduced Protein- Carbohydrate ratio.

A secondary stone occurs in the presence of infection, outflow obstruction, impaired bladder emptying or a foreign body. It originates in the bladder. Ammonium urate is the most common secondary bladder stone.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1509.

questions.text: A 75 years old male patient presents with complaints of poor voiding, straining, hesitancy and increased frequency. USG shows following image, what is the finding seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Bladder diverticulum is demonstrated by ultrasound.

  • A bladder outlet obstruction causes hypertrophy of the bladder wall and increases intravesical pressure to as high as 150 cm H2 This results in the formation of a pulsiondiverticulum.
  • The mouth of the diverticulum is usually situated above and to the outer side of one ureteric orifice.
  • Exceptionally, it is near the midline behind the interureteric ridge.
  • An uninfected diverticulum of the bladder usually causes no symptoms.

Complications -

  • Recurrent urinary tract infections as the pouch cannot empty itself completely.
  • Bladder stones
  • Peridiverticulitis can cause dense adhesions between the diverticulum and surrounding structures.
  • Squamous cell metaplasia and neoplasia are infrequent complications.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1491.

questions.text: A 27 years old male patient presents with complaints of on and off discharge from umbilicus. His CT scan image is as below. What is the spot diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows a large urachal cyst.

The intraabdominal portion of allantois is termed the urachus and connects the urinary bladder with the umbilicus. At the end of gestation, it is converted into the median umbilical ligament.

Persistence of part or all of the urachus may result in the formation of -

  • Vesicocutaneous fistula-with the appearance of urine at the umbilicus.
  • Extraperitoneal urachal cyst- presenting as a lower abdominal mass.
  • Urachal sinus- with the drainage of a small amount of mucus.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1495.

questions.text: All of the following are causes for vesico-vaginal fistula, except?
questions.solution:
Anterior colporrhaphy can lead to formation of vesicovaginal fistula.

Causes of vesicovaginal fistula include -

  • Obstetric- Protracted or neglected labour.
  • Gynaecological- Total hysterectomy and anterior colporrhaphy.
  • Radiotherapy.
  • Direct neoplastic infiltration. Exceptionally, carcinoma of the cervix ulcerates through the anterior fornix to implicate the bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1505.

questions.text: A 29 years old male presents with complaints of worsening of intense urinary frequency, urgency and small quantity voids. Cystogram image is as below. What is the spot diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Retrograde cystography shows a thimble bladder (exceedingly contracted bladder). This is seen in tuberculous cystitis.

  • Secondary to renal tuberculosis.
  • Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone.
  • The earliest evidence is pallor of the mucosa due to submucous oedema.
  • Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.
  • In longstanding cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced causing thimble bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1472.

questions.text: After resection of bladder tumour, check cystoscopies are recommended for all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
The factors that result in an increased recurrence and progression rate are:

  • high grade;
  • pT1 disease;
  • concomitant CIS;
  • multiple primary tumours;
  • recurrent disease at the first check cystoscopy 3 months after diagnosis.

Patients with known bladder tumours should always be screened for upper tract tumours. Very few present with advanced constitutional symptoms and a palpable mass. Microscopic haematuria should be evaluated to exclude urothelial malignancy in the high-risk adult (chronic smokers, occupational exposure, older age) population.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1481.

choices.text: Bimanual examination should be performed before and after resection of the tumour
Complete urinary tract assessment should be performed, including CT, MR and IV urography
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy does not improve survival rates
Locally advanced disease may be downstaged by radiotherapy or chemotherapy to enable salvage cystectomy

questions.text: Which statement is not correct regarding muscle invasive bladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy improves survival rates.

Muscle invasive bladder carcinoma -

  • Includes T2, T3 and T4
  • Has the worst prognosis as the incidence of metastasis is much more common.
  • Complete urinary tract assessment should be performed, including CT, MR and IV urography
  • A bimanual examination performed both before and after surgery helps in staging these tumours. The bladder should be empty. A mass palpable bimanually at the end of the procedure is stage pT3. When invasion has spread into the prostate in a man or the vagina in a woman it is classified as pT4a. If the tumour is fixed to the lateral pelvic side wall it is staged as pT4b.

Treatment -

  • Radical cystectomy, urinary diversion and thorough lymph node dissection f/b chemotherapy is done depending on the stage of the tumor.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy improves survival rates.
  • Locally advanced disease may be downstaged by radiotherapy or chemotherapy to enable salvage cystectomy.

The management depends upon the stage, grade and risk stratification. Low-risk localised tumours may be managed with endoscopic ablation or segmental excision. Kidney-sparing surgery is important in patients with solitary kidney, renal insufficiency and synchronous bilateral tumours. High-risk tumours warrant radical nephroureterectomy with bladder cuff resection with or without lymphadenectomy. Locally advanced disease is usually treated with cisplatinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy to downstage the disease prior to surgical ablation. Adjuvant chemotherapy has been shown to improve survival.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1481.
